Award.AwardTitle: Applications of Random Matrix Theory to Analytic Number Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project explores several problems at the intersection of random matrix theory and analytic number theory. The first of these areas historically draws much of its impetus from mathematical physics and broadly concerns statistical patterns found in matrices where entries have been chosen at random; ideas from this area have found applications in a large number of subjects ranging from epidemiology to telecommunications. The second area makes use of mathematical analysis to study properties of the integers -- for instance to study the distribution of primes or the way large integers tend to factor; these are natural problems which mathematicians have been interested in for a long time and which have applications to data-security. The two areas were first linked by the surprising and still largely conjectural resemblance between the local distribution of zeros of L-functions -- these are certain functions which are of central interest in analytic number theory -- and the distribution of eigenvalues of a random matrix. In fact, distributions of this sort have been found in a diverse range of situations, and it is an important problem to understand why these distributions arise so universally.

In more detail, the project consists of two related parts. The first is to study the link between zeros of L-functions and eigenvalues of random matrices by making use of combinatorial decompositions of arithmetic functions; analogous decompositions can be found in a function field setting and have shed light on related problems there. The second part is to investigate the extent to which certain pseudo-random walks on compact matrix groups equidistribute in the same fashion as classical random walks do; results pertaining to this second project have recently been used to resolve open questions about the distribution of certain trigonometric polynomials. The two components of the project share in common the use they make of combinatorial representation theory and also their study of sequences of random variables that are weakly dependent, with a dependence characterized by arithmetic/combinatorial considerations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Random matrix theory studies the properties of matrices which have random entries. An important part of the theory concerns the distribution of eigenvalues of random matrices. A random matrix can be thought of geometrically, as a random transformation of space, but the topic has found much broader applications to many parts of science,including multivariate statistics, nuclear physics, population dynamics, and wireless communication.

In the 1970s an amazing connection was discovered between random matrix theory and number theory, a subject of investigation which includes the distribution of prime numbers and many other unsolved problems. A central object in number theory is the Riemann zeta-function, which contains information about the distribution of the prime numbers.  The Riemann Hypothesis, regarding the location of the zeros of this function, was formulated in 1859 and is considered by some to be the most important open problem in pure mathematics. What was discovered experimentally around1980 by computer is that random matrix models appear to accurately describe the distribution of zeros of the Riemann zeta function. Random matrix theory has since been used to make many predictions in number theory, which can usually be confirmed through computer experiments but which have only then been proved in a few instances. In the other direction, results and questions in number theory have suggested new investigations in random matrix theory itself.

 

In Intellectual Merit, the research supported by the grant included work proving a conjecture of the mathematical physicist Charles M. Newman, which asserts that if the Riemann hypothesis is true, then it is ``just barely so." Other research investigated another possible distribution of zeros of the zeta function, called the ``Alternative Hypothesis", which does not come from standard random matrix theory and which is seen as being bizarre and desirable to disprove. By constructing an explicit counterexample distribution, this research showed that bizarre though it is, the Alternative Hypothesis statistics are compatible with the current  information known rigorously about the zeros. This sheds light on what will be required to disprove it.  In addition research supported by this grant investigated the link between the distribution of certain arithmetic functions and random matrix theory.

In Broader Impacts, the grant supported the training of two graduate students, one in random matrix theory and one in analytic number theory. The research  results were  disseminated as publically available preprints,  and seminar and conference talks were given on the results.
